title: John H. Winder
text:
John Henry Winder (February 21, 1800 – February 7, 1865) was a career <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> officer who served with distinction during the <a href="Mexican%E2%80%93American%20War">Mexican–American War</a>. He later served as a <a href="Confederate%20States%20of%20America">Confederate</a> <a href="general%20officer">general officer</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>.
Winder was noted for commanding <a href="prisoner-of-war%20camp">prisoner-of-war camp</a>s throughout the <a href="Southern%20United%20States">South</a> during the war, and for charges of improperly supplying the prisoners in his charge.
Early life and career.
<a href="Winder%20%28surname%29">Winder</a> was born at "Rewston" in <a href="Somerset%20County%2C%20Maryland">Somerset County, Maryland</a>, a son of U.S. Army <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">Brig. Gen.</a> <a href="William%20H.%20Winder">William H. Winder</a> and his wife Gertrude Polk. Winder's father fought in the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>, most notably, as the American commander, in the disastrous and rallying defeat at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bladensburg">Battle of Bladensburg</a> and was a second cousin to future Confederate general <a href="Charles%20Sidney%20Winder">Charles Sidney Winder</a>.
In 1814, Winder entered the <a href="United%20States%20Military%20Academy">United States Military Academy</a> at <a href="West%20Point%2C%20New%20York">West Point</a>, and graduated 11th of 30 cadets in 1820. He was commissioned a <a href="Second%20Lieutenant%23United%20States">second lieutenant</a> in the <a href="artillery">artillery</a>, and served first at <a href="Fort%20McHenry">Fort McHenry</a> in <a href="Baltimore%2C%20Maryland">Baltimore, Maryland</a>, and then in Florida.
During the early 1820s, Winder went through numerous transfers, going from the U.S. Rifle Regiment in 1820, to the 4th U.S. Artillery. Winder resigned his commission on August 31, 1823, and would not return to the Army for almost four years.
On the 12th of February 1823, he married Elizabeth Shepherd. The next year his father died, placing him in deep economic strain, and his mother was forced to turn her home into a boardinghouse. Winder failed to manage his father-in-law's plantation successfully, and he was unable to help his mother. In 1826, Elizabeth died, leaving him to raise their young son <a href="William%20A.%20Winder">William A. Winder</a>, which forced him back into the U.S. Army.
On April 2, 1827, Winder was reinstated as a second lieutenant, and he served in the 1st U.S. Artillery. He was promoted to <a href="First%20Lieutenant%23United%20States">first lieutenant</a> on November 30, 1833. He taught tactics at <a href="United%20States%20Military%20Academy">West Point</a> in 1827 where he met <a href="Jefferson%20Davis">Jefferson Davis</a> and <a href="Robert%20E.%20Lee">Robert E. Lee</a>, but lost his position after one year having lost his temper with a cadet. Winder served as the 1st Artillery's <a href="regiment">regiment</a>al <a href="adjutant">adjutant</a> from May 23, 1838, until January 20, 1840. He was promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28United%20States%29">captain</a> on October 7, 1842.
Mexican-American War.
Winder fought with distinction in Mexico, winning <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> promotions to <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> on August 20, 1847 (for his conduct at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Contreras">Battle of Contreras</a> and for the <a href="Battle%20of%20Churubusco">Battle of Churubusco</a>), and to <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20States%29">lieutenant colonel</a> on September 14 (for the <a href="Battle%20for%20Mexico%20City">Battle for Mexico City</a>.) He was wounded in an encounter near the Belén Gate when a piece of bone from the skull of one of his men scratched him in the face.
At the battle of Chapultepec, Winder was responsible for attacking the <a href="Military%20Academy">Military Academy</a> that was defended by <a href="Felipe%20Xicot%C3%A9ncatl">Felipe Xicoténcatl</a> and a few hundred cadets. While Winder's forces succeeded in either killing and capturing many of the cadets, that battle became a key part of Mexico's patriotic lore known as the <a href="Ni%C3%B1os%20H%C3%A9roes">Niños Héroes</a>. In 1947, <a href="President%20Harry%20S.%20Truman">President Harry S. Truman</a> on a visit to Mexico City made an unscheduled stop at the stone monument to the child heroes. In front of Mexican cadets standing at attention, Truman placed a floral wreath helping to heal the century old wound.
American Civil War.
Winder resigned his U.S. Army commission on April 20, 1861 and offered his services to the state of North Carolina. He was appointed a <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a> in the <a href="Confederate%20States%20Army">Confederate Army</a> <a href="infantry">infantry</a> on May 21. He was then promoted to <a href="Brig.%20Gen.%20%28CSA%29">brigadier general</a> on June 21 and the next day was made Assistant <a href="Inspector%20General">Inspector General</a> of the Camps of Instruction that were in the Confederacy's capital of <a href="Richmond%2C%20Virginia">Richmond, Virginia</a>, a post he would hold until October 21.
On March 1, 1862, Jefferson Davis declared martial law in Richmond and appointed Winder provost marshal general. Winder designated Samuel B. Maccubbin chief of detectives and gave him a force of <a href="Plug%20Uglies">Plug Uglies</a> imported from Baltimore to police the population of Richmond. Winder's first order was established <a href="prohibition">prohibition</a> of alcohol and required all citizens to surrender their firearms. Even though there were daily accusations or entrapment and corruption against his "plug-ugly" police force, Winder refused to order an investigation. By October 1864 newspapers reported the crime rate in Richmond exceeded the worst days of Baltimore or New York and much of the blame went to the corrupt police force. This earned him the moniker "The Dictator of Richmond".
In addition to his duties involving prisons, he was responsible for dealing with <a href="Desertion">deserters</a>, local law enforcement, and for a short time setting the commodity prices for the residents of a city dealing with a doubled population. During this time, he commanded <a href="Libby%20Prison">Libby Prison</a> in Richmond as well.
In April 1864, Winder appointed Captain <a href="Henry%20Wirz">Henry Wirz</a> commandant of a new prison camp in Georgia called Camp Sumter, better known as the infamous <a href="Andersonville%20National%20Historic%20Site">Andersonville Prison</a>. Winder commanded the Department of <a href="Henrico%20County%2C%20Virginia">Henrico</a> for much of the war, until May 5, 1864. He then commanded the 2nd District of the Department of North Carolina & Southern Virginia from May 25 until June 7. Ten days later, he briefly commanded Camp Sumter himself, until July 26. Winder then was given command of all military prisons in Georgia as well as those in <a href="Alabama%20in%20the%20American%20Civil%20War">Alabama</a> until November 21, when he was put in charge of the Confederate Bureau of Prison Camps, a post which he held until his death on February 7, 1865.
The assignment to run prisons in the South during the Civil War was a difficult job at best, hampered by the Confederacy's poor supply system combined with diminishing resources. In their post-war writings, some of the high level leaders of the Confederate government voiced the difficulties of Winder's assignment, saying:
During the war, Winder was frequently derided in <a href="Northern%20United%20States">Northern</a> newspapers, which accused him of intentionally starving Union prisoners. Military historian <a href="Ezra%20J.%20Warner%20%28historian%29">Ezra J. Warner</a> believes these charges were without merit, saying, "Winder adopted every means at his command to assure that the prisoners received the same ration as did Confederate soldiers in the field, scanty as that allotment was."
However, John McElroy's eyewitness account in his 1879 memoir "Andersonville" appears to contradict this. McElroy depicts Winder as boasting that he was "killing off more Yankees than twenty regiments in Lee's Army." McElroy claims that on July 27, 1864, Winder issued an order that if Union troops (under <a href="George%20Stoneman">General Stoneman</a>) were to come within seven miles of Andersonville, the guards were to "open upon the Stockade [i.e. upon the prisoners] with grapeshot, without reference to the situation beyond these lines of defense."
The major causes of the high mortality rates in Andersonville, Florence, and other prisons overseen by Winder were <a href="scurvy">scurvy</a> (which is easily avoided with inexpensive food sources of vitamin C) and exposure. Most prisoners had to sleep on the ground, even in freezing weather. The camp was in a wilderness area surrounded by forest, but the prisoners generally were not permitted to build huts or make campfires to cook their daily ration — about a pint of poorly ground corn meal. At the post-war trial of Captain <a href="Henry%20Wirz">Henry Wirz</a>, who was in charge of Andersonville, dozens of nearby residents testified that there was plenty of food available in that part of Georgia at the time.
It was suggested that Winder's controversial tenure as Richmond's provost marshal in 1862–1864 and commissary general of Confederate prisons in 1864–1865 exemplified the inefficient administrative system run by the Confederate Government.
Death and legacy.
Winder died on duty in <a href="Florence%2C%20South%20Carolina">Florence, South Carolina</a>, of a heart attack in 1865. His body was brought back to <a href="Maryland">Maryland</a> and interred at <a href="Green%20Mount%20Cemetery">Green Mount Cemetery</a> in <a href="Baltimore%2C%20Maryland">Baltimore</a>.
During the Civil War, Camp Winder and the Winder Hospital in Richmond were named after him.
After the Civil War, Winder's son, Capt. William Sidney Winder unsuccessfully tried to clear his father's name. 
Winder appears as a character in <a href="MacKinlay%20Kantor">MacKinlay Kantor</a>'s 1955 novel "<a href="Andersonville%20%28novel%29">Andersonville</a>", which won the <a href="Pulitzer%20Prize%20for%20Fiction">Pulitzer Prize for Fiction</a>.
In 1965, a sign recognizing Winder was erected in <a href="Salisbury%2C%20Maryland">Salisbury, Maryland</a>, near the intersection of U.S. Business 13 and U.S. 50 where a historically Black neighborhood was razed in 1950s to make room for the highways. In 1983, due to damage from traffic accidents, the sign was moved to the <a href="Wicomico%20County%20Courthouses">Wicomico County Courthouse</a> in Salisbury. On June 12, 2020 the sign recognizing Winder was removed. The Winder sign had been the focus of protests for years and was the subject of the 2018 documentary titled "The Sign".
